subsection.title: Graphing Equations

assemblage.p: An equation of the form y=ax+b, where a and b are constants, is called a linear equation because its graph is a straight line.

subsection.p: We can graph a linear equation by evaluating the expression ax+b at several values of x and then plotting points.

statement.p:
At 6 am the temperature was 50 \degree, and it has been rising by 4 \degree every hour.
Write an equation for the temperature, T, after h hours.

subsection.title: Cartesian Coordinate System
subsection.p: Many graphs include negative values as well as positive values. To make such a graph, we construct a Cartesian coordinate system, named after the French mathematician and philosopher Ren√© Descartes.

We draw two perpendicular number lines for the horizontal and vertical axes. The two axes divide the plane into four quadrants, or regions, as shown below. We often use x for the input variable and y for the output variable, so the horizontal axis is called the x-axis and the vertical axis is the y-axis. The axes intersect at the zero point of each number line. The coordinates of this intersection point, called the origin, are (0,0).

statement.p: What are the coordinates of the origin?
True or False: The x-coordinate of any point on the y-axis is zero.

The figure below shows how to plot points on a Cartesian grid. Points in the upper right quadrant have both coordinates positive. Points with negative x-coordinates are plotted to the left of the x-axis, and points with negative y-coordinates are plotted below the y-axis.
For example, the point (-2,1) is plotted 2 units to the left of the x-axis and 1 unit above the y-axis. In which quadrant are both coordinates negative?
True or False: The notation (5,3) represents two points, one on the x-axis and one on the y-axis.
True or False: If both coordinates of a point are negative, the point is located in the lower left quadrant.

assemblage.title: Graphing Tip #1
assemblage.p: If the coefficient of x (the number multiplying x) is a fraction, we can make our work easier by choosing multiples of the denominator for the x-values. That way we won't have to work with fractions to find the y-values. In Example 4, the coefficient of x is \dfrac{-2}{3}, so we choose multiples of 3 for the x-values.

We see that y has been replaced by -2 in the equation of the graph. So we look for the point on the graph that has y-coordinate -2. This point, labeled P on the graph below, has x-coordinate -3. graph Because it lies on the graph, the point P(-3,-2) is a solution of the equation ~y=\dfrac{-2}{3}x-4. When we substitute x=-3 and y=-2 into the equation, we get a true statement: -2=\dfrac{-2}{3}(-3)-4 But this statement also tells us that -3 is a solution of the equation ~\dfrac{-2}{3}x-4=-2.

assemblage.title: Graphing Tip #2
assemblage.p: When you graph a linear equation, you should extend the line far enough in both directions so that it will cross both the x-axis and the y-axis. The points where the graph crosses the axes are important for applications.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: The graph of an equation is a picture of the solutions of the equation. Each point on the graph represents a solution. If a point lies on the graph, its coordinates make the equation true.
